column1: The Mikoyan MiG-29 (Russian: Микоян МиГ-29; NATO reporting name: Fulcrum) is a twin-engine jet fighter aircraft designed in the Soviet Union. Developed by the Mikoyan design bureau as an air superiority fighter during the 1970s
column2: the MiG-29
column3: along with the larger Sukhoi Su-27
column4: was developed to counter new U.S. fighters such as the McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle and the General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon. The MiG-29 entered service with the Soviet Air Forces in 1982.

column1: While originally oriented towards combat against any enemy aircraft
column2: many MiG-29s have been furnished as multirole fighters capable of performing a number of different operations
column3: and are commonly outfitted to use a range of air-to-surface armaments and precision munitions. The MiG-29 has been manufactured in several major variants
column4: including the multirole Mikoyan MiG-29M and the navalised Mikoyan MiG-29K; the most advanced member of the family to date is the Mikoyan MiG-35. Later models frequently feature improved engines
column5: glass cockpits with HOTAS-compatible flight controls
column6: modern radar and infrared search and track (IRST) sensors
column7: and considerably increased fuel capacity; some aircraft have also been equipped for aerial refueling.

column1: Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union
column2: the militaries of a number of former Soviet republics have continued to operate the MiG-29
column3: the largest of which is the Russian Air Force. The Russian Air Force wanted to upgrade its existing fleet to the modernised MiG-29SMT configuration
column4: but financial difficulties have limited deliveries.  The MiG-29 has also been a popular export aircraft; more than 30 nations either operate or have operated the aircraft to date. As of 2013 the MiG-29 was still in production by Mikoyan
column5: a subsidiary of United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) since 2006.

column2: the United States Air Force (USAF) encountered difficulties over the skies of Vietnam. Supersonic fighter bombers that had been optimized for low altitude bombing
column3: like the F-105 Thunderchief
column4: were found to be vulnerable to older MiG-17s and more advanced MiGs which were much more maneuverable. In order to regain the limited air superiority enjoyed over Korea
column5: the US refocused on air combat using the F-4 Phantom multi-role fighter
column6: while the Soviet Union developed the MiG-23 in response. Towards the end of the 1960s
column7: the USAF started the "F-X" program to produce a fighter dedicated to air superiority
column8: which led to the McDonnell Douglas F-15 Eagle being ordered for production in late 1969.At the height of the Cold War
column9: a Soviet response was necessary to avoid the possibility of a new American fighter gaining a serious technological advantage over existing Soviet fighters. Thus the development of a new air superiority fighter became a priority. In 1969
column10: the Soviet General Staff issued a requirement for a Perspektivnyy Frontovoy Istrebitel (PFI
column11: roughly "Advanced Frontline Fighter").  Specifications were extremely ambitious
column13: good short-field performance (including the ability to use austere runways)
column16: and heavy armament. The Russian aerodynamics institute TsAGI worked in collaboration with the Sukhoi design bureau on the aircraft's aerodynamics.By 1971
column18: Soviet studies determined the need for different types of fighters. The PFI program was supplemented with the Perspektivnyy Lyogkiy Frontovoy Istrebitel (LPFI
column19: or "Advanced Lightweight Tactical Fighter") program; the Soviet fighter force was planned to be approximately 33% PFI and 67% LPFI.  PFI and LPFI paralleled the USAF's decision that created the "Lightweight Fighter" program and the General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon and Northrop YF-17. The PFI fighter was assigned to Sukhoi
column21: while the lightweight fighter went to Mikoyan. Detailed design work on the resultant Mikoyan Product 9
column24: with the first flight taking place on 6 October 1977. The pre-production aircraft was first spotted by United States reconnaissance satellites in November of that year; it was dubbed Ram-L because it was observed at the Zhukovsky flight test center near the town of Ramenskoye.The workload split between TPFI and LPFI became more apparent as the MiG-29 filtered into front line service with the Soviet Air Forces (Russian: Voenno-Vozdushnye Sily [VVS]) in the mid-1980s. While the heavy
column25: long range Su-27 was tasked with the more exotic and dangerous role of deep air-to-air sweeps of NATO high-value assets
column26: the smaller MiG-29 directly replaced the MiG-23 in the frontal aviation role.

column2: the new fighter was given the NATO reporting name "Fulcrum-A" because the pre-production MiG-29A
column3: which should have logically received this designation
column4: remained unknown in the West at that time. The Soviet Union did not assign official names to most of its aircraft
column5: although nicknames were common. Unusually
column6: some Soviet pilots found the MiG-29's NATO reporting name
column7: "Fulcrum"
column8: to be a flattering description of the aircraft's intended purpose
column9: and it is sometimes unofficially used in Russian service.The MiG-29B was widely exported in downgraded versions
column10: known as MiG-29B 9-12A and MiG-29B 9-12B for Warsaw Pact and non-Warsaw Pact nations respectively
column11: with less capable avionics and no capability for delivering nuclear weapons.

column2: Mikoyan developed the improved MiG-29S to use longer range R-27E and R-77 air-to-air missiles. It added a dorsal 'hump' to the upper fuselage to house a jamming system and some additional fuel capacity. The weapons load was increased to 4
column4: 800 lb) with airframe strengthening. These features were included in new-built fighters and upgrades to older MiG-29s.

column1: Refined versions of the MiG-29 with improved avionics were fielded by the Soviet Union
column2: but Mikoyan's multirole variants
column3: including a carrier-based version designated MiG-29K
column4: were never produced in large numbers. Development of the MiG-29K carrier version was suspended for over a decade before being resumed; the type went into service with the Indian Navy's INS Vikramaditya
column5: and Russian Navy's Admiral Kuznetsov class aircraft carrier.

column1: Mikoyan had developed improved versions of the MiG-29
column2: called MiG-29M/M2 and MiG-29SMT. On 15 April 2014
column3: the Russian Air Force placed an order for a batch of 16 MiG-29SMT fighters.There have been several upgrade programmes conducted for the MiG-29. Common upgrades include the adoption of standard-compatible avionics
column4: service life extensions to 4
column5: 000 flight hours
column6: safety enhancements
column7: greater combat capabilities and reliability. In 2005
column8: the Russian Aircraft Corporation “MiG” established a unified family of 4++ generation multirole fighters: the aircraft carrier–based MiG-29K
column9: front-line MiG-29M and MiG-35 fighters.

column2: Russian deputy prime minister Dmitry Rogozin revealed that Russia was planning to build a new fighter to replace the MiG-29. The Sukhoi Su-27 and its derivatives were to be replaced by the Sukhoi Su-57
column3: but a different design was needed to replace the lighter MiGs. A previous attempt to develop a MiG-29 replacement
column4: the MiG 1.44 demonstrator
column5: failed in the 1990s. The concept came up again in 2001 with interest from India
column6: but they later opted for a variant of the Su-57. Air Force commanders have hinted at the possibility of a single-engine airframe that uses the Su-57's engine
column7: radar
column8: and weapons primarily for Russian service.

column1: Sharing its origins in the original PFI requirements issued by TsAGI
column2: the MiG-29 has broad aerodynamic similarities to the Sukhoi Su-27
column3: however
column4: there are some notable differences. The MiG-29 has a mid-mounted swept wing with blended leading-edge root extensions (LERXs) swept at around 40°; there are swept tailplanes and two vertical fins
column5: mounted on booms outboard of the engines. Automatic slats are mounted on the leading edges of the wings; they are four-segment on early models and five-segment on some later variants. On the trailing edge
column6: there are maneuvering flaps and wingtip ailerons.The MiG-29 has hydraulic controls and a SAU-451 three-axis autopilot but
column7: unlike the Su-27
column8: no fly-by-wire control system. Nonetheless
column9: it is very agile
column10: with excellent instantaneous and sustained turn performance
column12: and a general resistance to spins. The airframe consists primarily of aluminum with some composite materials
column13: and is stressed for up to 9 g (88 m/s²) maneuvers. The controls have "soft" limiters to prevent the pilot from exceeding g and alpha limits
column14: but the limiters can be disabled manually.

column1: The MiG-29 has two widely spaced Klimov RD-33 turbofan engines
column2: each rated at 50.0 kilonewtons (11
column3: 200 lbf) dry and 81.3 kilonewtons (18
column4: 300 lbf) in afterburner. The space between the engines generates lift
column5: thereby reducing effective wing loading
column6: hence improving maneuverability. The engines are fed through intake ramps fitted under the leading-edge extensions (LERXs)
column7: which have variable ramps to allow high-Mach speeds. As an adaptation to rough-field operations
column8: the main air inlet can be closed completely and the auxiliary air inlet on the upper fuselage can be used for takeoff
column9: landing and low-altitude flying
column10: preventing ingestion of ground debris. Thereby the engines receive air through louvers on the LERXs which open automatically when intakes are closed. However the latest variant of the family
column13: and adopted the mesh screens design in the main intakes
column14: similar to those fitted to the Su-27.The MiG-29 has a ferry range of 1
column15: 500 km (930 mi) without external fuel tanks
column18: 300 mi) with external tanks. The internal fuel capacity of the original MiG-29B is 4
column20: 153 US gal) distributed between six internal fuel tanks
column21: four in the fuselage and one in each wing. For longer flights
column22: this can be supplemented by a 1
column23: 500 l (330 imp gal; 400 US gal) centreline drop tank and
column26: 150 l (250 imp gal; 300 US gal) underwing drop tanks. In addition
column27: a newer models have been fitted with port-side inflight refueling probes
column28: allowing much longer flight times by using a probe-and-drogue system.

column1: The cockpit features a conventional centre stick and left hand throttle controls. The pilot sits in a Zvezda K-36DM ejection seat which has had impressive performance in emergency escapes.

column2: with a head-up display (HUD) and a Shchel-3UM helmet mounted display
column3: but no HOTAS ("hands-on-throttle-and-stick") capability. Emphasis seems to have been placed on making the cockpit similar to the earlier MiG-23 and other Soviet aircraft for ease of conversion
column4: rather than on ergonomics. Nonetheless
column5: the MiG-29 does have substantially better visibility than most previous Russian jet fighters
column6: thanks to a high-mounted bubble canopy. Upgraded models introduce "glass cockpits" with modern liquid-crystal (LCD) multi-function displays (MFDs) and true HOTAS.

column1: The baseline MiG-29B has a Phazotron RLPK-29 radar fire control system which includes the N019 Sapfir 29 look-down/shoot-down coherent pulse-Doppler radar and the Ts100.02-02 digital computer.
The N019 radar was not a new design
column2: but rather a development of the Sapfir-23ML architecture used on the MiG-23ML. During the initial design specification period in the mid-1970s
column3: Phazotron NIIR was tasked with producing a modern radar for the MiG-29. To speed development
column4: Phazotron based its new design on work undertaken by NPO Istok on the experimental "Soyuz" radar program. Accordingly
column5: the N019 was originally intended to have a flat planar array antenna and full digital signal processing
column6: for a detection and tracking range of at least 100 km (62 mi) against a fighter-sized target. Prototype testing revealed this could not be attained in the required timeframe and still fit within the MiG-29's nose. Rather than design a new radar
column7: Phazotron reverted to a version of the Sapfir-23ML's twisted-polarization cassegrain antenna and traditional analog signal processors
column8: coupled with a new NII Argon-designed Ts100 digital computer to save time and cost. This produced a working radar system
column9: but inherited the weak points of the earlier design
column10: plaguing the MiG-29's ability to detect and track airborne targets at ranges available with the R-27 and R-77 missiles.

column1: The N019 was further compromised by Phazotron designer Adolf Tolkachev’s betrayal of the radar to the CIA
column2: for which he was executed in 1986. In response to all of these problems
column3: the Soviets hastily developed a modified N019M Topaz radar for the upgraded MiG-29S aircraft. However
column4: VVS was reportedly still not satisfied with the performance of the system and demanded another upgrade. The latest upgraded aircraft offered the N010 Zhuk-M
column5: which has a planar array antenna rather than a dish
column6: improving range
column7: and a much superior processing ability
column8: with multiple-target engagement capability and compatibility with the Vympel R-77 (or RVV-AE).

column1: Armament for the MiG-29 includes a single GSh-30-1 30 mm (1.18 in) cannon in the port wing root. This originally had a 150-round magazine
column2: which was reduced to 100 rounds in later variants. Original production MiG-29B aircraft cannot fire the cannon when carrying a centerline fuel tank as it blocks the shell ejection port. This was corrected in the MiG-29S and later versions. Three pylons are provided under each wing (four in some variants)
column3: for a total of six (or eight). The inboard pylons can carry either a 1
column4: 150 l (250 imp gal; 300 US gal) fuel tank
column5: one Vympel R-27 (AA-10 "Alamo") medium-range air-to-air missile
column6: or unguided bombs or rockets. Some Soviet aircraft could carry a single nuclear bomb on the port inboard station. The outer pylons usually carry R-73 (AA-11 "Archer") dogfight air to air missiles
column7: although some users still retain the older R-60 (AA-8 "Aphid"). A single 1
column8: 500 l (330 imp gal; 400 US gal) tank can be fitted to the centerline
column9: between the engines.

column1: While the MiG-29's true capabilities could only be estimated from the time it first appeared In 1977 until the mid-1980s
column2: a combination of persistent intelligence and increasing access afforded by the Soviet foreign sales effort allowed a true appreciation of its capabilities.  Early MiG-29s were very agile aircraft
column3: capable of rivalling the performance of contemporary F-18 and F-16 aircraft.  However
column4: their relatively low fuel capacity relegated them to short-range air defense missions. Lacking HOTAS and an inter-aircraft data link
column5: and requiring a very intensive "heads-down" approach to operating cockpit controls
column6: the early MiG-29 denied pilots the kind of situational awareness routinely enjoyed by pilots operating comparable US aircraft. Analysts and Western pilots who flew examples of the MiG-29 thought this likely prevented even very good pilots from harnessing the plane's full combat capability. Later MiG-29s were upgraded to improve their capabilities.

column1: The Soviet Union exported MiG-29s to several countries. Because 4th-generation fighter jets require the pilots to have extensive training
column2: air-defense infrastructure
column3: and constant maintenance and upgrades
column4: MiG-29s have had mixed operational history with different air forces.

column1: The MiG-29 was first publicly seen in the West when the Soviet Union displayed the aircraft in Finland on 2 July 1986. Two MiG-29s were also displayed at the Farnborough Airshow in Britain in September 1988. The following year
column2: the aircraft conducted flying displays at the 1989 Paris Air Show where it was involved in a non-fatal crash during the first weekend of the show. The Paris Air Show display was only the second display of Soviet fighters at an international air show since the 1930s. Western observers were impressed by its apparent capability and exceptional agility. Following the disintegration of the Soviet Union
column3: most of the MiG-29s entered service with the newly formed Russian Air Force.

column2: two MiG-29s of the Russian Air Force collided in mid-air and crashed away from the public at the Royal International Air Tattoo. No one on the ground sustained any serious injuries
column3: and the two pilots ejected and landed safely.

column1: The Russian Air Force grounded all its MiG-29s following a crash in Siberia on 17 October 2008. Following a second crash with a MiG-29 in east Siberia in December 2008
column2: Russian officials admitted that most MiG-29 fighters in the Russian Air Force were incapable of performing combat duties due to poor maintenance. The age of the aircraft was also an important factor as about 70% of the MiGs were considered to be too old to take to the skies. The Russian MiG-29s have not received updates since the collapse of the Soviet Union. On 4 February 2009
column3: the Russian Air Force resumed flights with the MiG-29. However
column4: in March 2009
column5: 91 MiG-29s of the Russian Air Force required repair after inspections due to corrosion; approximately 100 MiGs were cleared to continue flying at the time. The Russian Air Force started an update of its early MiG-29s to the more current MiG-29SMT standard
column6: but financial difficulties prevented delivery of more than three MiG-29 SMT upgrade to the Russian Air Force.  Instead
column7: the 35 MiG-29SMT/UBTs rejected by Algeria were bought by the Russian Air Force. Russia placed an order for 16 new-build MiG-29SMTs on 15 April 2014
column8: with delivery expected by 2017.On 4 June 2015
column9: a MiG-29 crashed during training in Astrakhan. A month later
column10: another MiG-29 crashed near the village of Kushchevskaya in the Krasnodar region with the pilot safely ejecting. A series of accidents in the Russian Air Force that happened in 2015 were caused mostly by overall increase of flights and trainings.

column2: Georgian officials claimed a Russian MiG-29 shot down a Georgian Hermes 450 unmanned aerial vehicle and provided video footage from the ill-fated drone showing an apparent MiG-29 launching an air-to-air missile at it. Russia denies that the aircraft was theirs and says they did not have any pilots in the air that day. Abkhazia's administration claimed its own forces shot down the drone with an L-39 aircraft "because it was violating Abkhaz airspace and breaching ceasefire agreements." UN investigation concluded that the video was authentic and that the drone was shot down by a Russian MiG-29 or Su-27 using a R-73 heat seeking missile.On 16 July 2014
column3: a Ukrainian Su-25 was shot down
column4: with Ukrainian officials stating that a Russian MiG-29 shot it down using a R-27T missile. Russia denied these allegations.During the first half of September 2017
column5: the Russian Air Force deployed some MiG-29SMT multirole combat aircraft to Hmeymim airbase
column6: near Latakia
column7: in western Syria
column8: becoming the first time the modernized version of the baseline Fulcrum jet was deployed to take part in the Syrian Air War. The MiG-29SMT were involved in bombing missions and secondary strategic bombers escort duties.Two Russian MiG-29's operated by Wagner Group crashed near Sirte
column9: Libya on 28 June 2020 and on 7 September 2020. According to Russian website avia.pro at least one aircraft was shot down by a Turkish MIM-23 Hawk surface-to-air missile.

column2: during the military intervention in Crimea
column3: 45 Ukrainian Air Force MiG-29s and 4 L-39 combat trainers were reportedly captured by Russian forces at Belbek air base. Most of the planes appeared to be in inoperable condition. In May
column4: Russian troops dismantled them and shipped them back to Ukraine. On 4 August 2014
column5: the Ukrainian government stated that a number of them had been put back into service to fight in the war in the east of the country.During the initial days of the War in Donbass in April 2014
column6: the Ukrainian Air Force deployed some jet fighters over the Donetsk region to perform combat air patrols and show of force flights. Probably due to the limited number of jet fighters available
column7: a MiG-29 belonging to the Ukrainian Falcons display team was spotted armed with a full air-to-air load and performing a low altitude fly by.In the evening of 7 August 2014
column8: a Ukrainian Air Force MiG-29MU1
column9: bort number 02 Blue
column10: was shot down by an antiaircraft missile fired by pro-Russian rebels near the town of Yenakievo
column11: and exploded in midair. The pilot ejected safely.On 17 August 2014
column14: tasked with air to ground duties against rebel positions was shot down by pro-Russian rebels in the Luhansk region. The Ukrainian government confirmed the downing. The pilot ejected safely and was recovered by friendly forces.As of 2018
column15: the Lviv State Aviation Repair Plant began domestically upgrading the MiG-29 to have multirole capability
column16: known as the MiG-29MU2. Development is expected to be completed by 2019 and enter production in 2020. The first upgraded MiG-29 was delivered to the Ukrainian Air Force in July 2020. In August 2020
column17: Ukraine began negotiations with Elbit Systems to help modernize the MiG-29 fleet.On 29 May 2020
column18: Ukrainian MiG-29s took part in the Bomber Task Force in Europe with American B-1B bombers for the first time in the Black Sea region. In September 2020
column19: B-52 bombers from the 5th Bomb Wing conducted vital integration training with Ukrainian MiG-29s and Su-27s inside Ukraine's airspace.

column1: India was the first international customer of the MiG-29. The Indian Air Force (IAF) placed an order for more than 66 MiG-29s in 1980 while the aircraft was still in its initial development phase. Since its induction into the IAF in 1985
column2: the aircraft has undergone a series of modifications with the addition of new avionics
column3: sub-systems
column4: turbofan engines and radars.Indian MiG-29s were used extensively during the 1999 Kargil War in Kashmir by the Indian Air Force to provide fighter escort for Mirage 2000s attacking targets with laser-guided bombs.The MiG-29's good operational record prompted India to sign a deal with Russia in 2005–2006 to upgrade all of its MiG-29s for US$888 million. Under the deal
column5: the Indian MiGs were modified to be capable of deploying the R-77RVV-AE (AA-12 'Adder') air-to-air missile. The missiles had been successfully tested in October 1998 and were integrated into IAF's MiG-29s. IAF has also awarded the MiG Corporation another US$900 million contract to upgrade all of its 69 operational MiG-29s. These upgrades will include a new avionics kit
column6: with the N-109 radar being replaced by a Phazotron Zhuk-M radar. The aircraft is also being equipped to enhance beyond-visual-range combat ability and for air-to-air refuelling to increase endurance.  In 2007
column7: Russia also gave India's Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL) a licence to manufacture 120 RD-33 series 3 turbofan engines for the upgrade. The upgrade will also include a new weapon control system
column8: cockpit ergonomics
column9: air-to-air missiles
column10: high-accuracy air-to-ground missiles and "smart" aerial bombs. The first six MiG-29s will be upgraded in Russia while the remaining 63 MiGs will be upgraded at the HAL facility in India. India also awarded a multimillion-dollar contract to Israel Aircraft Industries to provide avionics and subsystems for the upgrade.

column2: the Indian Air Force expressed concern after 90 MiG-29s were grounded in Russia. After carrying out an extensive inspection
column3: the IAF cleared all MiG-29s in its fleet in March 2009. In a disclosure in Parliament
column4: Defence Minister A. K. Antony said the MiG-29 is structurally flawed in that it has a tendency to develop cracks due to corrosion in the tail fin. Russia has shared this finding with India
column5: which emerged after the crash of a Russian Air Force MiG-29 in December 2008. "A repair scheme and preventive measures are in place and IAF has not encountered major problems concerning the issue
column6:
Antony said. Despite concerns of Russia's grounding, India sent the first six of its 78 MiG-29s to Russia for upgrades in 2008. The upgrade program will fit the MiGs with a phased array radar (PESA) and in-flight re-fuelling capability.In January 2010, India and Russia signed a US$1.2 billion deal under which the Indian Navy would acquire 29 additional MiG-29Ks, bringing the total number of MiG-29Ks on order to 45.  The MiG-29K entered service with the Indian Navy on 19 February 2010.

The upgrades to Indian MiG-29s will be to the MiG-29UPG standard.  This version is similar to the SMT variant but differs by having a foreign-made avionics suite. The upgrade to latest MiG-29UPG standard is in process, which will include latest avionics, Zhuk-ME Radar, engine, weapon control systems, enhancing multirole capabilities by many-fold.  As of 2012, Indian UPG version is the most advanced MiG-29 variant. The Director-General of MiG, Sergei Korotkov said, The most advanced is the MiG-29UPG
column7: implemented in India in collaboration with local industry".  The first three aircraft were delivered in December 2012
column8: over two years behind schedule. The IAF is in advanced stages of talks to buy a new squadron of upgraded multi-role MiG-29s from Russia using three-decade old MiG-29s.An IAF MiG-29 crashed near Jalandhar in Punjab on 8 May 2020 with its pilot ejected safely after the aircraft failed to respond. A court of inquiry has been ordered in the incident.

column1: Yugoslavia was the first European country outside the Soviet Union to operate the MiG-29. The country received 14 MiG-29Bs and two MiG-29UBs from the USSR in 1987 and 1988. The MiG-29s were put into service with the 127th Fighter Aviation Squadron
column2: based at Batajnica Air Base
column3: north of Belgrade
column4: Serbia.Yugoslav MiG-29s saw little combat during the breakup of Yugoslavia
column5: and were used primarily for ground attacks. Several Antonov An-2 aircraft used by Croatia were destroyed on the ground at Čepin airfield near Osijek
column6: Croatia in 1991 by a Yugoslav MiG-29
column7: with no MiG-29 losses. At least two MiG-29 carried out an air strike on Banski dvori
column8: the official residence of the Croatian Government
column9: on 7 October 1991.The MiG-29s continued their service in the subsequent Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. Because of the United Nations arms embargo against the country
column10: the condition of the MiG-29s worsened.A total of six MiG-29s were shot down during the NATO intervention in the Kosovo War
column11: of which three were shot down by USAF F-15s
column13: and one by a RNLAF F-16. One aircraft
column15: was hit by friendly fire from the ground.  Another four were destroyed on the ground. One Argentine source claims that a MiG-29 shot down an F-16 on 26 March 1999
column17: as the F-16C in question was said to have crashed in the US that same day.

column1: The Air Force of Serbia and Montenegro continued flying its remaining five MiG-29s at a very low rate after the war with one of them crashing on 7 July 2009. In spring 2004
column2: news appeared that MiG-29 operations had ceased
column3: because the aircraft could not be maintained
column4: but later the five remaining airframes were sent to Russia for overhauling. The small Serbian MiG-29 fleet along with other jets were grounded for four months during Summer 2014 due to a battery procurement issue. The Serbian Air Force operates three MiG-29s as of late 2014
column5: with one airframe grounded due to structural issues.In November 2016
column6: Russia had agreed to donate six of its MiG-29s free of charge
column7: if Serbia would pay the repair costs of $50 million for them. At the end of January 2017
column8: Serbian defense minister Zoran Đorđević said that Belarus also agreed to donate eight of its MiG-29s to Serbia on a no-pay basis. In early October 2017
column9: Russia completed the delivery of all the six MiG-29s. The aircraft were transferred to Serbia on board the Antonov An-124 transport aircraft. On 25 February 2019
column10: Belarus formally handed four MiG-29s to the Serbian military during a ceremony held at the 558th Aircraft Repair Plant in Baranavichy. This increased the total number of MiG-29s in the Serbian Air Force to 14. Serbia plans to spend about €180–230 million on modernization of its entire MiG-29 fleet.

column2: four MiG-29UBs)
column3: which entered service in 1988–1989 in 1./JG3 "Wladimir Komarow" in Preschen in Brandenburg. After the fall of the Berlin Wall in November 1989 and reunification of Germany in October 1990
column4: the MiG-29s and other aircraft of the East German Air Forces of the National People's Army were integrated into the West German Luftwaffe. Initially the 1./JG3 kept its designation. In April 1991 both 1./JG3's MIG-29 squadrons were reorganised into the MIG-29 test wing ("Erprobungsgeschwader MIG-29")
column5: which became JG73 "Steinhoff" and was transferred to Laage near Rostock in June 1993.

column1: The Federation of American Scientists claims the MiG-29 is equal to
column2: or better than the F-15C in some areas such as short aerial engagements because of the Helmet Mounted Weapons Sight (HMS) and better maneuverability at slow speeds. This was demonstrated when MiG-29s of the German Air Force participated in joint DACT exercises with US fighters. The HMS was a great help
column3: allowing the Germans to achieve a lock on any target the pilot could see within the missile field of view
column4: including those almost 45 degrees off boresight. However the German pilots who flew the MiG-29 admitted that while the Fulcrum was more maneuverable at slow speeds than the F-15 Eagle
column5: F-16 Fighting Falcon
column6: F-14 Tomcat
column7: and F/A-18 Hornet and its Vympel R-73 dogfight missile system was superior to the AIM-9 Sidewinder of the time
column8: all of the American-made fighters had superior avionics
column9: radar
column10: and beyond visual range missiles. In engagements that went into the beyond visual range arena the German pilots found it difficult to multi-task locking and firing the MiG-29's Vympel R-27 missile (German MiG-29s did not have access to the more advanced Vympel R-77 that equips other nations' MiG-29s) while trying to avoid the longer range and advanced search and track capabilities of the American fighters' radars and AIM-120 AMRAAM. The Germans also stated that the American fighters had the advantage in both night and bad weather combat conditions. The Luftwaffe's assessment of the MiG-29 was that the Fulcrum was best used as a point defense interceptor over cities and military installations; not for fighter sweeps over victim airspace. This assessment ultimately led Germany to not deploy its MiG-29s in the Kosovo War during Operation Allied Force
column11: though Luftwaffe pilots who flew the MiG-29 admitted that even if they were permitted to fly combat missions over the former Yugoslavia they would have been hampered by the lack of NATO specific communication tools and Identification friend or foe systems.Beginning in 1993
column12: the German MiGs were stationed with JG73 "Steinhoff" in Laage near Rostock. During the service in the German Air Force
column13: one MiG-29 ("29+09") was destroyed during an accident on 25 June 1996 due to pilot error. By 2003
column14: German Air Force pilots had flown over 30
column15: 000 hours in the MiG-29. In September 2003
column16: 22 of the 23 remaining machines were sold to the Polish Air Force for the symbolic price of €1 per item. The last aircraft were transferred in August 2004. The 23rd MiG-29 ("29+03") was put on display at Laage.

column1: In 2020 it is reported that MiG-29 aircraft was flown by forces aligned with Haftar in Libya. In September 2020 US Africa Command stated that two MiG-29s
column2: operated by Russian speaking personnel
column3: were crashed in Libya due to unknown reasons.

column1: The Peruvian Air Force acquired 21 MiG-29S fighters from Belarus in 1997
column2: as part of a package that also included 18 Su-25 attack aircraft. The following year an additional 3 MiG-29 aircraft were acquired from Russia. At the same time
column3: Peru contracted with Mikoyan to upgrade 8 aircraft to the MiG-29SMP standard
column4: with an option to upgrade the remainder of the Peruvian inventory.  The Peruvian MiG-29s are based at FAP Captain José Abelardo Quiñones González International Airport in northern Peru
column5: equipping Escuadrón Aéreo 612 (Fighter Squadron 612 "Fighting Roosters").

column2: three MiG-29UB) were delivered to Poland in 1989–1990. The aircraft were based at Mińsk Mazowiecki and used by the 1st Fighter Aviation Regiment

column4: or 1st Tactical Squadron (TS). In 1995–1996

column7: and MiG-21s in 2004
column8: Poland was left for a time with only these 22 MiG-29s in the interceptor role.

column1: Of the 22 MiG-29s Poland received from the German Air Force in 2004
column2: a total of 14 were overhauled and taken into service. They were used to equip the 41st Tactical Squadron (41. elt)
column3: replacing its MiG-21s. As of 2008
column4: Poland was the biggest NATO MiG-29 user. The possibility of modernizing the fighters to enable them to serve until 2020–2025 is being contemplated
column5: depending on whether cooperation with Mikoyan can be established. Poland has 31 active MiG-29s (25 MiG-29As
column6: 6 MiG-29UBs) as of 2017. They are stationed with the 1st Tactical Squadron at the 23rd Air Base near Mińsk Mazowiecki and the 41st TS at the 22nd Air Base near Malbork.

column1: There have been unconfirmed reports that Poland had at one point leased a MiG-29 from its own inventory to Israel for evaluation and the aircraft has since been returned to Poland
column2: as suggested by photographs of a MiG-29 in Israeli use. Three Polish MiG-29A were reported in Israel for evaluation between April and May 1997 at Negev desert. On 7 September 2011
column3: the Polish Air Force awarded a contract to the WZL 2 company to modernise its MiG-29 fleet to be compatible with Polish F-16s.Four MiG-29s from 1. elt performed Baltic Air Policing Quick Reaction Alert mission in 2006
column4: while 41. elt aircraft in 2008
column5: 2010 and 2012. Polish MiG-29s played the aggressor role in NATO Tactical Leadership Programme (TLP) joint training program in Albacete
column6: Spain in 2011
column7: 2012 and 2013.On 18 December 2017
column8: a MiG-29 crash-landed in a forest near 23rd Air Base while performing a landing approach. The pilot survived.  Reports afterward were contradictory whether he ejected or not. On 21 December 2017
column9: the MoD confirmed that the pilot did not eject. This was the first crash of a MiG-29 during its nearly three decades–long operational history in the Polish Air Force. On 6 July 2018
column11: with its pilot dying in an ejection attempt. Technical issues are suspected to have played a role in the crash. Another crash followed on 4 March 2019. This time the pilot ejected and survived.

column1: Iraq received a number of MiG-29 fighters and used them to engage Iranian equivalent opponents during the later stages of the Iran–Iraq War.
MiG-29s also saw combat in the 1991 Persian Gulf War with the Iraqi Air Force. Five MiG-29s were shot down by USAF F-15s. Some Russian sources reported that one British Panavia Tornado
column2: ZA467
column3: was shot down in northwestern Iraq by a MiG-29 piloted by Jameel Sayhood.  UK sources claim this Tornado to have crashed on 22 January on a mission to Ar Rutbah.  Other Iraqi air-to-air kills are reported in Russian sources
column4: where the US claims other cases of combat damage
column5: such as a B-52 which the US claims was hit by friendly fire
column6: when an AGM-88 high-speed
column7: anti-radiation missile (HARM) homed on the fire-control radar of the B-52's tail gun; the bomber returned to base and was subsequently renamed "In HARM's Way". It is believed that an F-111 was hit by MiG-29 but it was able to return to base.Iraq's original fleet of 37 MiG-29s was reduced to 12 after the Gulf War. One MiG-29 was damaged
column8: and four were evacuated to Iran. The remaining 12 aircraft were withdrawn from use in 1995 because the engines needed to be overhauled but Iraq could not send them off for that work.After the American-led 2003 invasion of Iraq and disbandment of the Ba'athist Iraqi Army in May of the same year
column9: the remaining Russian-made and Chinese-made fighters of Iraqi forces had been decommissioned.

column1: Syrian Arab Air Force MiG-29s have sometimes encountered Israeli fighter and reconnaissance aircraft. Two Israeli F-15Cs reportedly shot down two MiG-29As on 2 June 1989 under unclear circumstances.Further reports claim that on 14 September 2001 two Syrian Air Force MiG-29s were shot down by two Israeli F-15Cs while the MiGs were intercepting an Israeli reconnaissance aircraft off the coast of Lebanon. However
column2: both Syria and Israel deny that this occurred.Syrian MiG-29s entered the Syrian Civil War in late October 2013
column3: attacking Free Syrian Army insurgents with unguided rockets and bombs in Damascus.A Syrian MiG-29SM crashed on 7 March 2020 near Shayrat Airbase. Marking the first crash of the plane in the Syrian Air Force since 2001. According to avia.pro the aircraft may have been shot down by MANPADS operated by the Syrian Opposition.

column1: There have been occasional claims regarding the use of Sudanese Air Force MiG-29s against insurgent forces in Darfur. However
column2: whereas Mi-24 combat helicopters as well as A-5 or
column3: more recently
column4: Su-25 ground-attack aircraft have been spotted and photographed on Darfurian air fields
column5: no MiG-29s have been observed. On 10 May 2008
column6: a Darfur rebel group
column7: the Justice and Equality Movement (JEM) mounted an assault on the Sudanese capital. During this action
column8: the JEM shot down a Sudanese Air Force MiG-29 with 12.7 and 14.5 mm (0.500 and 0.571 in) heavy machine gun fire while it was attacking a convoy of vehicles in the Khartoum suburb of Omdurman. The aircraft was piloted by a Russian mercenary. He was killed in action as his parachute did not open after ejecting. On 14 November 2008 Sudanese Ministry of Defence admitted that Sudan had received 12 MiG-29 from Russia. An anonymous Russian source claimed that the aircraft had been delivered before 2004During the brief 2012 South Sudan–Sudan border conflict
column9: on 4 April 2012
column10: Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) claimed the downing of a Sudanese MiG-29 using antiaircraft guns. The Sudan government denied the claim. On 16 April 2012
column11: the SPLA issued a second claim about the downing of a Sudanese MiG-29. It was not clear if this second claim referred to the previous one.

column2: the United States purchased 21 Moldovan MiG-29 aircraft under the Nunn–Lugar Cooperative Threat Reduction program. Fourteen were MiG-29S models
column3: which are equipped with an active radar jammer in its spine and are capable of being armed with nuclear weapons. Part of the United States’ motive to purchase these aircraft was to prevent them from being sold to Iran. This purchase could also provide the tactical jet fighter communities of the USAF
column4: the USN and the USMC with a working evaluation and data for the MiG-29
column5: and possibly for use in dissimilar air combat training. Such information may prove valuable in any future conflicts and can aid in the design and testing of current and future weapons platforms. In late 1997
column6: the MiGs were delivered to the National Air and Space Intelligence Center (NASIC) at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio
column7: though many of the former Moldovan MiG-29s are believed to have been scrapped.  Some of these MiG-29s are currently on open display at Nellis AFB
column8: Nevada; NAS Fallon
column9: Nevada; Goodfellow AFB

column1: The Korean People's Air Force is believed to operate about 40 MiG-29Bs and MiG-29SEs divided into the 55th and 57th fighter regiments based at Sunchon and Onchon
column2: respectively. These were first encountered and photographed by the USAF in March 2003 when a pair of KPAF MiG-29s intercepted an USAF RC-135S reconnaissance aircraft.

column1: A Cuban MiG-29UB shot down two Cessna 337s belonging to the organisation Brothers to the Rescue in 1996
column2: after the aircraft approached Cuban airspace.According to some reports
column3: in the 1999 Eritrean-Ethiopian War
column4: a number of Eritrean MiG-29s were shot down by Ethiopian Su-27s piloted by Russian mercenaries. (It is true that local pilots were trained by instructors from those nations.) There are also some other reports of Eritrean MiG-29s shooting down two Ethiopian MiG-21s
column5: three MiG-23s
column6: and a Su-25.The Bangladesh Air Force (BAF) currently operates 8 MiG-29s (6SE & 2UB).Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh went to Moscow and signed a major arms deal including naval patrol vessels
column7: training of Yemeni military personnel and a purchase of up to 44 upgraded MiG-29s. The deal successfully went ahead and Yemen also received two additional jets from Kazakhstan. Russia trained 15 pilots on MiG-29s. Equipped with N019MP radar and an advanced fire control system they became the most advanced combat aircraft the Yemeni Air force has had. They are compatible with Kh-31 and Kh-29 guided air to ground missiles and R-77 guided air to air missiles.

column2: Russia moved to expand its military influence in the Middle East when it announced it was giving Lebanon 10 fighter jets
column3: that would have been the most significant upgrade of Lebanon's military since the civil war ended almost two decades before. A Russian defense ministry representative said it was giving secondhand MiG-29s to Lebanon for free. This was to be part of a defense cooperation deal that would have seen Moscow train Lebanese military personnel. On 29 February 2010
column4: Russia agreed to change the offer to 10 Mi-24 attack helicopters based on a Lebanese request. The Argentine Air Force will seek to purchase over 15 MiG-29 multirole fighters from Russia.

column1: Initial production version; entered service in 1983. NATO reporting name is "Fulcrum-A". 9.12A is the Initial production model version for Warsaw Pact while the 9.12B is the downgraded export version for non-Warsaw Pact nations. 9.12A lacks a nuclear weapon delivery system and has initial production radar
column2: ECM and IFF (no ECM and IFF in 9.12B).MiG-29UB (Product 9.51)

column1: Twin seat training model. Infra-red sensor mounted only
column2: no radar. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-B". Export variant had downgraded systems similar to MiG-29 9.12.

column1: === Upgraded variants based on original airframe ===

column2: given the NATO reporting code "Fulcrum-C"
column3: features flight control system improvements; a total of four new computers provide better stability augmentation and controllability with an increase of 2° in angle of attack (AoA). An improved mechanical-hydraulic flight control system allows for greater control surface deflections. The MiG-29S has a dorsal hump
column4: which led to its nickname "Fatback"
column5: houses the L-203BE Gardenyia-1 ECM system. The MiG-29S can carry 1
column6: 150 l (250 imp gal; 300 US gal) under wing drop tanks and a centerline tank. The inboard underwing hardpoints allow a tandem pylon arrangement for carrying a larger payload of 4
column8: 800 lb). Overall maximum gross weight has been raised to 20
column10: 000 lb). Built only for domestic use.  Early MiG-29S featured an IRST sighting system; the MiG-29S improvement kit includes the Phazotron N019M radar and Built-In Test Equipment (BITE) to reduce dependence on ground support equipment; MiG MAPO designates this as MiG-29SD. Improvements to software and processing capabilities enables the tracking of up to 10 targets and the simultaneous engagement of two with the R-77 missile. The MiG-29S also has a limited ground-attack capability.MiG-29SE

column1: Export model of MiG-29S with slightly downgraded N-019ME radar with multiple target tracking ability and RVV-AE (R-77 missile) compatibility. The first export model MiG-29 with underwing drop tanks; the inner underwing pylons can carry over 500 kg (1
column2: 100 lb) bombs in side by side tandem pairs.  Its weapons mix includes R-27T1
column3: R-27ER1 and R-27ET1 medium-range missiles. The aircraft can be fitted with active ECM systems
column4: weapons guidance aids
column5: improved built-in check and training systems. The MiG-29SE can simultaneously engage two air targets.MiG-29SM (Product 9.13M)

column2: but with the ability to carry guided air-to-surface missiles and TV- and laser-guided bombs. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-C".MiG-29SM (SyAF)
and based on the MiG-29SM
column3: except the Syrian MiG-29SM uses the 9.12 airframe.  RAC MiG developed a special variant for Syria.

column1: East German MiG-29 / 29UB upgraded to NATO standards
column2: with work done by MiG Aircraft Product Support GmbH (MAPS)
column3: a joint venture company form between MiG Moscow Aviation Production Association and DaimlerChrysler Aerospace in 1993.MiG-29AS/MiG-29UBS (MiG-29SD)

column1: Slovak Air Force performed an upgrade on their MiG-29/-29UB for NATO compatibility. Work is done by RAC MiG and Western firms
column2: starting from 2005. The aircraft now has navigation and communications systems from Rockwell Collins
column3: an IFF system from BAE Systems
column4: new glass cockpit features multi-function LC displays and digital processors and also fitted to be integrate with Western equipment in the future. However
column5: the armaments of the aircraft remain unchanged. 12 out of 21 of the entire MiG-29 fleet were upgraded and had been delivered as of late February 2008.

column1: Upgrade planned for Romanian Air Force
column2: by Israeli firms. First flight occurred on 5 May 2000. The program was halted along with the retiring of Romanian MiG-29s in 2003. The latter occurred because of high maintenance costs
column3: which led to the Romanian Government's decision to halt the MiG-29 program and further invest in the MiG-21 LanceR program.

column1: The MiG-29SMT is an upgrade package for first-generation MiG-29s (9.12 to 9.13) containing enhancements intended for the MiG-29M variant. Additional fuel tanks in a further enlarged spine provide a maximum flight range of 2
column3: 300 mi) on internal fuel. The cockpit has an enhanced HOTAS design
column4: two 152 mm × 203 mm (6.0 in × 8.0 in) colour liquid crystal MFDs and two smaller monochrome LCDs. The MiG-29A was not designed for an advanced air-to-ground capability
column5: this is substantially improved by the SMT upgrade; features include air-to-ground radar detection and integrated air-to-ground guided weapons. The upgraded Zhuk-ME radar provides similar features to the MiG-29M. The power plant are upgraded RD-33 ser.3 engines with afterburning thrust rated at 81 kN (18
column6: 000 lbf) each. The weapons load was increased to 4
column8: 900 lb) on six underwing and one ventral hardpoints
column9: with similar weapon choices as for the MiG-29M. The upgraded aircraft can also accommodate non-Russian origin avionics and weapons.MiG-29BM

column2: possibly Bolyshaya Modernizaciya – large modernization) is an upgrade to the MiG-29 conducted by the ARZ-558 aircraft repair plant in Baranovichi
column3: Belarus. The MiG-29BM is a strike variant of the MiG-29 pure fighter
column4: the Belarusian counterpart to the Russian MiG-29SMT. It includes improvements to weapons
column5: radar
column6: as well as adding non-retractable air-air refueling ability. They entered service in 2003 and it is estimated
column7: that ten or so were modernized to BM standard.MiG-29UBT (Product 9.51T)

column1: SMT standard upgrade for the MiG-29UB. Namely users
column2: Algeria and Yemen.MiG-29UPG

column1: The Indian UPG version is similar to the SMT variant but differs by having a foreign-made avionics suite integrated within it
column2: in the "international avionics suite". The weapons suite is the same as the SMT and K/KUB versions. The design is a new modification intended for the MiG-29s used by Indian Air Force. It made its maiden flight on 4 February 2011. The standard includes the new Zhuk-M radar
column3: new avionics
column4: a IFR probe as well as new enhanced RD-33 series 3 turbofan engines. The modernization is part of a $900 million contract to upgrade the 69 fighters fleet. In 2012
column5: RAC MiG general director's stated the UPG version was the "most advanced" MiG-29 variant.MiG-29SMP / MiG-29UBP

column1: Upgrade for the Peruvian Air Force MiG-29 fleet. In August 2008 a contract of US$106 million was signed with RAC MiG for this custom SM upgrade of an initial batch of eight MiG-29
column2: with a provision for upgrade of the remainder of the Peruvian MiG-29 fleet. The single-seat version is designated SMP
column3: whereas the twin-seat version is designated UBP.The SMP standard features an improved ECM suite
column4: avionics
column5: sensors
column6: pilot interface
column7: and a MIL-STD-1553 databus.  The interfaces include improved IRST capabilities for enhanced passive detection and tracking as well as better off-boresight launch capabilities
column8: one MFCD and HOTAS. The N019M1 radar
column9: a heavily modified and upgraded digital version of the N019 radar
column10: is used instead of the standard N010 Zhuk-M used on the MiG-29SMT. The upgrade also includes a structural life-extension program (SLEP)
column12: upgrade of the original engines and the installation of an in-flight refuelling probe.MiG-29MU1

column1: Ukrainian modernization of MiG-29. Range of detection of air targets increased up to 29% (up to 100 km (62 mi) in the forward hemisphere and up to 45 km (28 mi) at the rear).

column2: with a redesigned airframe
column3: mechanical flight controls replaced by a fly-by-wire system and powered by enhanced RD-33 ser.3M engines. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-E".MiG-29UBM (Product 9.61)

column1: Two-seat training variant of the MiG-29M. Never built. Effectively continued under the designation 'MiG-29M2'.MiG-29M2 / MiG-29MRCA
Two-seat version of MiG-29M. Identical characteristics to MiG-29M
column2: with a slightly reduced ferry range of 1
column4: 100 mi). RAC MiG presented in various air shows
column5: including Fifth China International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition (CIAAE 2004)
column6: Aero India 2005
column7: MAKS 2005. It was once given designation MiG-29MRCA for marketing purpose and now evolved into the current MiG-35.

column1: The aircraft is one of the six pre-built MiG-29Ms before 1991
column2: later received thrust vectoring engine and fly-by-wire technology. It served as a thrust-vectoring engine testbed and technology demonstrator in various air shows to show future improvement in the MiG-29M. It has identical avionics to the MiG-29M. The only difference in the cockpit layout is an additional switch to turn on vector thrust function. The two RD-133 thrust-vectoring engines
column3: each features unique 3D rotating nozzles which can provide thrust vector deflection in all directions. However
column4: despite its thrust-vectoring
column5: other specifications were not officially emphasized. The aircraft is being demonstrated along with the MiG-29M2 in various air shows around the world for potential export. The aircraft is usually used as an aerobatic demonstrator.

column2: the letter "K" stands for "Korabelnogo bazirovaniya" (deck-based). It features folding wings
column3: arrestor gear
column4: and reinforced landing gear. Originally intended for the Admiral Kuznetsov class aircraft carriers
column5: it had received series production approval from the Russian Ministry of Defence but was grounded in 1992 due to shift in military doctrine and financial difficulties. The MiG Corporation restarted the program in 1999. On 20 January 2004
column6: the Indian Navy signed a contract of 12 single-seat MiG-29K and four two-seat MiG-29KUB. Modifications were made for the Indian Navy requirement. Production MiG-29K and MiG-29KUB share a two-seater size canopy. The MiG-29K has radar absorbing coatings to reduce radar signature. Cockpit displays consist of wide HUD and three (seven on MiG-29KUB) colour LCD MFDs with a Topsight E helmet-mounted targeting system. It has a full range of weapons compatible with the MiG-29M and MiG-29SMT. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-D".MiG-29KUB (Product 9.47)

column1: Identical characteristic to the MiG-29K but with tandem twin seat configuration. The design is to serve as trainer for MiG-29K pilot and is full combat capable. The first MiG-29KUB developed for the Indian Navy made its maiden flight at the Russian Zhukovsky aircraft test centre on 22 January 2007. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-D".MiG-35
A recently unveiled mature development of the MiG-29M/M2 and MiG-29K/KUB. NATO reporting code is "Fulcrum-F".

column2: Washington. The aircraft was obtained from Eastern Europe in early 2009. The aircraft has an FAA approved maintenance program and is flyable.

column2: Illinois. This aircraft was purchased by Don Kirlin from Kyrgyzstan. It is available for contract training and flight testing.

column1: Two MiG-29UBs in flying condition were offered for sale from Eastern Europe in spring 2009. These aircraft come from the same source as the flyable aircraft owned by the Historic Flight Foundation.
